text:
(1)

105-109 East Houston Street, south side, between the Bowery and Chrystie Street, showing St. Augustine's Chapel (Trinity Parish). It is one of the striking architectural features of the city and is a Chapel of Old Trinity, erected in 1876. It has two main parts, a mission house and the church proper. The five floors of the mission house contain a large hall, school, guild-rooms and a parish room. The work is almost entirely among the indigent classes of the neighborhood. Besides a Sunday-school, it has a day school for boys and a night school for both men and women; giving instruction in sewing and cooking.
March 13, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

A portion of the same, showing the rear of the belfry as seen from the Fisher Building (adjoining the church). Also shown is a general view, northward, of the neighboring area; with Second Ave. seen on the left.

July 17, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

105-109 East Houston Street, south side, between the Bowery and Chrystie Street, showing St. Augustine's Chapel (Trinity Parish). It is one of the striking architectural features of the city and is a Chapel of Old Trinity, erected in 1876. It has two main parts, a mission house and the church proper. The five floors of the mission house contain a large hall, school, guild-rooms and a parish room. The work is almost entirely among the indigent classes of the neighborhood. Besides a Sunday-school, it has a day school for boys and a night school for both men and women; giving instruction in sewing and cooking.
March 13, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

A portion of the same, showing the rear of the belfry as seen from the Fisher Building (adjoining the church). Also shown is a general view, northward, of the neighboring area; with Second Ave. seen on the left.

July 17, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

109 to 95 East Houston Street, south side, west from but not including (left, not shown) Chrystie Street, to the Bowery, showing St. Augustine's Chapel (Trinity Parish) at Nos. 109-105, and the 11-story Fisher Building (Nos. 103-97). Also shown, at the N.W. corner of Second Ave., is construction work in progress on the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway) after demolition of the houses which formerly occupied the site. St. Augustine's Chapel was erected in 1876 and is considered to be a striking architectural feature of New York. It has two parts, a mission house and the church proper. The mission house contains a large hall, guild and school-rooms. The work is almost entirely among the poorer classes of the neighborhood and includes social activities of a varied nature. June 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, a slightly limited view. June 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

109 to 95 East Houston Street, south side, west from but not including (left, not shown) Chrystie Street, to the Bowery, showing St. Augustine's Chapel (Trinity Parish) at Nos. 109-105, and the 11-story Fisher Building (Nos. 103-97). Also shown, at the N.W. corner of Second Ave., is construction work in progress on the Independent System Subway (Eighth Ave. subway) after demolition of the houses which formerly occupied the site. St. Augustine's Chapel was erected in 1876 and is considered to be a striking architectural feature of New York. It has two parts, a mission house and the church proper. The mission house contains a large hall, guild and school-rooms. The work is almost entirely among the poorer classes of the neighborhood and includes social activities of a varied nature. June 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, a slightly limited view. June 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

111-117 East Houston Street, at the S.W. corner of Chrystie Street (the foot of Second Ave.), showing the National (formerly known as the Thomashefsky) Theatre, a Jewish legitimate stage playhouse, as seen from a point on Second Ave. Also shown (indistinctly) is Chrystie Street, west side, south from and including East Houston Street. On the right is visible a portion of St. Augustine's Chapel (105-109 East Houston Street).

June 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

Chrystie Street, west side, south from East Houston, to Canal Streets, as seen from East Houston Street, and across clearance during the construction of the Sarah Delano Roosevelt Park.

March 16, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) "Bocci" (Italian bowling) is still played by Italian Americans. View at East Houston and Chrystie Streets. May 8, 1934. P. L. Sperr.  Neg # 2710.

(2) The same; a more distant view. May 8, 1934. P. L. Sperr.
title: Recreation and hobbies - Games (Bocci).
